document.masterDocTitle: Acrotritia species (Acari: Oribatida: Euphthiracaridae) from China with description of a new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Acrotritia species (Acari: Oribatida: Euphthiracaridae) from China with description of a new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Measurements. Prodorsum: length 248–270 , width 179–195 , height 94–108 , setae: ss 60–72 , ro 50–54 , in 105–112 , le 60–65 , ex 5–6 , mutual distance: in–in 80 , le–le 45 , ro–ro 35 ; notogaster: length 452–560 , width 310–410 , height 312–402 ; c 1 65–68 , c 2 60–64 , c 3 60–64 , c p 60–65 , d 1 60–65 , d 2 50–52 ,
e 1 62
–65,
e 2 49
–52, h 1 64–69 , h 2 60–63 , h 3 60–62 , ps 1 60–64 , ps 2 55–57 , ps 3 50–54 , mutual distance: c 1 – d 1 110 , d 1 – e 1 140 , e 1 – h 1 82 , h 1 – ps 1 85 ; genito-aggenital plate 152 × 70 , ano-adanal plate 215 × 59 .

Colour yellowish to brown; prodorsum abruptly humped near insertion level of rostral setae in lateral view; one pair of long and strong lateral carinae present; sensilla with flat and truncate head, covered with small spines distally; prodorsal setae robust, rigid and barbed in distal half, except exobothridial setae; notogastral setae fairly short, similar in shape to lamellar setae; vestigial setae f 1 situated ventrad to setae h 1 ; 9 pairs of minute genital setae present, including 1 pair of setae inserted on progenital area; 2 pairs of aggenital setae located longitudinally; tarsi of legs I bidactylous, tarsi II–IV heterotridactylous.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Acrotritia hauseri (Mahunka, 1991)
: A, lateral view of body (legs removed); B, prodorsum, dorsal view; C, sensillum, dorsal view; D, ventral plate; E–G, trochanter, femur, genu and tibia: E, leg I; F, leg II; G, leg III; H, femur, genu and tibia: leg IV. Scale bars: A–B, D–H=100 µm; C=50 µm.

Remarks. The genus
Acrotritia
is not easy to deal with from the standpoint of systematics as there are few reliable morphological features. After studying thousands of specimens of this group these years, we found out that the shape of prodorsum is a “good and stable” feature that can be applied in the taxonomy. From this view, we considered
A. hauseri
as a valid species (synonymized with
A. ardua
by
Niedbała ( 2011 ))
, because it can be distinguished from the latter by the prodorsum abruptly humped near insertion level of rostral setae.

Compared with holotype , the specimens from China only differ by the position of aggenital setae (close to anterior margin of genito-aggenital plates versus remote in holotype ). In our opinion, this arrangement of aggenital setae is very unusual in this genus. Before rechecking the type specimen, this question can not be well solved. Here we tentatively identify these specimens as
A. hauseri
.
